data:
A printed book delves into debates about cosmetics, beauty, and racial purity in seventeenth-century England.  

Miso-Spilus (1600s) 
A wonder of wonders, or A metamorphosis of fair faces voluntarily transformed into foul visages: or, an invective against black-spotted faces
London: John Grismond, 1662

Because they could conceal or enhance different aspects of one’s complexion, cosmetics became a flashpoint for English anxieties about white purity in the seventeenth century. Some commenters worried that women’s use of make-up might make it more difficult to be certain about their racial background. Cosmetics might make white women appear mixed-race—or enable women of color to pass as white.  

Miso-Spilus (1600s) 
A wonder of wonders, or A metamorphosis of fair faces voluntarily transformed into foul visages: or, an invective against black-spotted faces
London: John Grismond, 1662

Europeans invented a number of theories to understand racial difference. One seventeenth-century fringe theory proposed that Black Africans had developed darker skin by using cosmetics. Pseudoscientific ideas like this justified European racial divisions, but also offered a rationale for controlling women’s fashion: left to their own cosmetic devices, white women risked damaging their racial purity. 

John Bulwer (fl. 1648–54), author
Portrait of spotted faces from Anthropometamorphosis: man transform'd; or, The artificiall changling historically presented...
London: William Hunt, 1653

Plays and poetry reveal what was stylish and desirable in seventeenth-century England, just as TV, popular fiction, and social media do today. Dark patches and beauty spots were à la mode, but poets described pristine white skin as the height of female beauty—often in specific contrast to Black and brown women’s complexions. 

Richard Lovelace (1618–58), author
“Another” from Lucasta, Posthume poems of Richard Lovelace
London: William Godbid, 1659–60
